senses.definition: ' in the dark' If you're in the dark about something, you don't know anything about it.
example: It's getting dark. [j33] We couldn't see in the dark cave. [j33] When I got back the house was completely dark
She has dark hair. [j33] You should wear a dark suit. [j33] I bought a dark blue dress

Jared always looks on the dark side of things. [j33] He's been in a dark mood all week. [j33] The economic outlook is still very dark.  4 ' '[cf2]adjective Dark can also mean that someone is angry or threatening.  [cf2]Shelley gave me dark looks when I talked to her boyfriend
Luke's little brother is afraid of the dark. [j33] In winter I set off for work in the dark and I get home in the dark. [j33] Their footsteps echoed through the dark
I want to be home before dark. [j33] Don't go out alone after dark
They kept us in the dark about the proposed changes. [j33] I'm still in the dark about what I'm supposed to be doing
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb darken' The sky darkened as the storm rose.   His face darkened at the news.[j35] 'noun darkness' Darkness fell as we waited.  The park is closed during the hours of darkness.

example: There are seven days in a week. [j33] I'll be away for about ten days
It was cloudy all day today. [j33] Our cat sleeps during the day
Did you have a good day ~at work? [j33] Our doctor works a 12-hour day. [j33] I was off sick for three days last week
In my grandfather's day, it was only a small village. [j33] Although people remember Ned Kelly, the day of the bushranger is long gone

I'm tired of doing this[j4]let's call it a day. [j33] They never made any money at the business, and decided to call it a day. 6 ' in those days' '[cf2] In those days means 'at that period'.  [cf2]Bill was manager in those days
These days we use a computer. [j33] I hardly see Jenny these days

definition: Daybreak is the time in the morning when it begins to get light.
note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is dawn.
example: I always go for a swim at daybreak

definition: A day care centre is a place where you can take your young children to be looked after while you are at work during the day
note: ... OTHER EXPRESSIONS for this are day centre, child-care centre and creche.

definition: If you daydream, you don't concentrate on what you're doing, but allow yourself to imagine pleasant things.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun daydream' Her voice roused me from my daydream.
example: Carlos often sits at his desk daydreaming about surfing

senses.definition: ' daylight saving' Daylight saving is a system of advancing the clock forward by an hour or more during the summer months.  This gives you more hours of daylight at the end of the working day.  Most Australian states practise daylight saving.
example: We've still got three hours of daylight left, so let's keep driving
During daylight saving, 5 o'clock standard time becomes 6 o'clock summer time

senses.definition: ' daylight saving' Daylight saving is a system of advancing the clock forward by an hour or more during the summer months.  This gives you more hours of daylight at the end of the working day.  Most Australian states practise daylight saving.
example: We've still got three hours of daylight left, so let's keep driving
During daylight saving, 5 o'clock standard time becomes 6 o'clock summer time

definition: Daytime is the part of a day between sunrise and sunset.
example: It's hard to sleep in the daytime when you work at night

definition: If you are dazed, you are uncertain about your surroundings because of a blow or a ~sudden shock.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun daze' I walked around in a daze.
example: The boxer was dazed by the blow to his chin. [j33] The news of her father's death left her dazed for a week

senses.definition: ' If you dazzle someone, you amaze and impress them with your skill or beauty.
example: I was dazzled by the car's headlights. [j33] When we came out of the cinema our eyes were dazzled by the sun light
Her brilliant performance dazzled the audience
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective dazzling' She gave a dazzling display of talent.   It was painted a dazzling yellow.[j35]'adverb dazzlingly' She's dazzlingly beautiful.  His teeth are dazzlingly white.

senses.definition: ' the dead' You refer to people who have died as the dead.
example: The teller was dead, shot in the bank raid. [j33] I threw away the dead flowers. [j33] They found a dead body in the undergrowth. 2 ' '[cf2]adjective If a part of your body goes dead, you have no feeling in it.  [cf2]The dentist gave me an injection to make my gum go dead. [j33] I tried to move, but my legs were completely dead
After living in the city, I found the small country town completely dead. [j33] The party was pretty dead until Jake arrived. [j33] The business district's always dead at weekends
There was dead silence in the room when he entered. [j33] The train came to a dead stop
I prefer not to speak ill of the dead. [j33] The dead were swept hastily into mass graves
note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is numb.   3' 'adjective If a telephone, battery or piece of electrical equipment is dead, it isn't working.  The battery was dead so we couldn't start the car.  The line went dead in the middle of our conversation. 4 ' 'adjective If you feel dead after working or exercising, you're very tired.  I'm usually dead after a day of travelling.
... WORD FAMILY 'verb See deaden'. [j35]'adjective See deadly'. [j35]'noun See death'.

definition: If something deadens a sound or a feeling, it makes it weaker or duller.
example: The thick curtains and double-glazed windows deadened the noise of the traffic outside. [j33] The injection deadened the pain of his broken leg

definition: If a road is a dead end, you can't drive right through it because it's closed to traffic at one end
'times,0'[cp8
example: 5][j24]de-end' If you're in a dead- end job or situation, you have little or no chance of improving it.  It appears to lead nowhere

definition: When a race ends in a dead heat, two or more competitors finish at exactly the same time
A dead letter is a letter that remains unclaimed at the post office, or one that cannot be delivered because it is addressed incorrectly
A deadline is the time or date by which you have to finish something.
example: The deadline for the essay is 5 o'clock on Friday

senses.definition: ' A deadlock is a situation where neither side in an argument is willing to compromise or give in.
example: The peace talks have reached a complete deadlock
' A deadlock is also a lock on a door which needs a key to open it whether you are outside or inside. This makes it difficult for burglars to remove goods from your house
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb deadlock' Deadlock your door for security.

senses.definition: ' turn a deaf ~ear' If you turn a deaf ear to something, you refuse to listen or pay attention to it.
senses.rest: [nb
example: The Australian box jellyfish is one of the deadliest creatures in the sea so be careful when you're swimming. [j33] ...a deadly poison
I'm not joking, I'm deadly serious. [j33] ...deadly boring. [j33] ...deadly accurate.  [cj3,6,9]--deaf 'times,0'[cp8.5]def'[cp8
' If someone is deaf, they are unable to hear anything or they can't hear very well
Carla continued on her way, deaf to his advice. [j33] David was deaf to his surroundings as he worked on the model boat
' the deaf' You refer to people who are deaf as the deaf
I turned a deaf ear to the kids' protests, and bundled them into the car
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb deafen' I was deafened by the noise of the machinery.[j35]'adjective deafening' The train rushed past with a deafening roar.[j35]'noun deafness' He suffers from profound deafness.

senses.definition: ' deal with'  (a) When you deal with a particular situation or problem, you take action to bring about the result you want.
example: We made a deal not to argue about money again. [j33] I got a good deal on the old fridge. [j33] The deal is that the second adult pays half price
Deal every player ten cards before you start
We've had a good deal of rain this year. [j33] It still hurts a great deal. [j33] You'll need to run a good deal faster if you want to win
The shop on the corner deals in Asian antiques

The police had trouble dealing with the huge traffic jam. [j33] I've got far more work than I can deal with. '  (b) '[cf2] When you deal with people, you treat or handle them in a particular way.  [cf2]He's not very good at dealing with people. [j33] Patti deals with her staff very fairly and honestly. '  (c) '[cf2] If a book, film or talk deals with a particular topic, it is about that topic.  [cf2]The second chapter deals with Australian bushrangers. [j33] The film deals sensitively with the issue of prostitution. [j33] You haven't dealt with the international aspect in enough detail
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See dealer'. [j35]'noun See dealings'.

senses.definition: ' Something that is dear costs a lot of money.  It is expensive.

' A deck of cards is a set of 52 playing cards

senses.definition: ' When you declare your income, or goods that you want to bring into the country, you tell the tax department or customs officers about them so that you can pay the right amount of tax or duty.
example: She declared her resignation the next day. [j33] Ken was reluctant to declare his love for her
The customs officer asked me whether I had anything to declare. [j33] If you don't declare all your income, you'll be fined

' In cricket, when the side which is batting declares, it closes its innings before all ten wickets have fallen.  They do this because they have a lot of runs and want to get the other side out before the end of the match

example: Tony denied having stolen the money. 2 ' '[cf2]verb If you deny someone something, you refuse to give it to them.  [cf2]Giovanni was denied permission to drive his mother's car ever again

definition: Deodorant is a chemical substance that prevents or removes unpleasant smells, especially those of your body
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb deodorise (or deodorize)' We had to deodorise the car after the dog had slept in it.

senses.definition: ' When someone or some~ thing departs from a place, they leave it.
example: When will Jan depart for Fiji? [j33] The train departs at noon. 2 ' depart from' '[cf2] When you depart from a certain way of doing something, you start doing it in a different way.  [cf2]The government is unwilling to depart from its economic policy
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun departure' Jan's departure is on the 9th of January.

definition: In formal language, a departed person is someone who has died.
example: The RSL holds ceremonies to honour departed comrades who died in the war

definition: A department is a section of a larger organisation such as a business, government, school, university or store.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective departmental' ...a depart~ mental head.
example: Peter works in the accounts department. [j33] ...the shoe department

senses.definition: ' If you say one thing depends on another, you mean that it will be decided by, or influenced by, that other thing.
example: Your baby depends on you for food and warmth
You can depend on Wolfgang to always be on time. [j33] I can ~always depend on my car to start first thing in the morning
Whether we go fishing or not on Saturday depends on the weather. [j33] The trip depends on whether we can save enough money
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective dependable' He's a very dependable person.[j35]'adjective See dependent'. [j35]'adjective See dependant'.

definition: A dependant is someone who relies on you for financial support, food, clothing and housing.
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this with dependent.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'verb See depend'.
example: Rajir has four dependants[j4]his elderly mother and his three children

definition: 'A dependent person or thing relies on, or needs to be supported by, someone or something else.
note: ... DO NOT CONFUSE this with dependant.  [j32] ... THE OPPOSITE of this is independent.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'verb See depend'. [j35]'noun depend~ ence' He has a dependence on drugs.[j35]'noun dependency ' He has a dependency on drugs.
example: Developing countries are heavily dependent on foreign aid. [j33] ...a dependent child

definition: When you depict something, you describe it in words, or show it in pictures.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun depiction' ...an accurate depiction of life in the 1860s.
example: The painting depicts a typical Australian landscape

definition: When you deplete some~ thing, you reduce it in amount or contents.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun depletion' ...a serious deple~ tion of stocks.
example: The strike has depleted the goods available on the supermarket shelves

definition: If you deplore something, you feel or express sorrow and regret for it.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective deplorable' Pollution is absolutely deplorable.
example: I deplore the amount of pollution and waste we put into the seas

definition: When a country deports someone, it sends them away because they have broken the law or have no legal right to be there. ~
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun deportation' He was threat~ ened with deportation.[j35]'noun deportee' Ranlee and the other deportees had to leave their belongings behind in Russia.
example: When caught, illegal immigrants are deported. [j33] Russia deported the American spies

senses.definition: ' Someone's deportment is also the way they behave and conduct themselves.
example: Julie's deportment is very elegant
If her deportment doesn't improve, she'll be expelled from the ladies college

definition: When a ruler or leader is deposed, they are removed from their position of power by force.
example: The president was deposed in the military coup

example: Kim deposits half his pay in his savings account every week
Millions of years ago, gold was deposited in these rocks
A deposit on a house is usually 10% of the purchase price. [j33] Hu left a $1000 deposit on his new car
These rowing boats cost $35 a day to hire, together with a $50 deposit
' A deposit is also an amount of money you have put in the bank
Rich deposits of gold were found in Victoria in the 1860s
' A deposit is also a layer of matter, such as dust, that collects on a surface
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See depository'.

senses.definition: ' out of your depth'  If you are out of your depth, you have reached a point where you no longer understand something or can no longer cope with a situation.
example: The pool is two metres in depth at this point. [j33] You need a dish with greater depth
The box is 28 cm in length, 14 cm in width and 12 cm in depth. [j33] The photograph has a wonderful sense of depth
Look at the depth of the blue in the ocean. [j33] Richard found it hard to express the depth of his love
They filmed the strange creatures that live in the depths of the ocean. [j33] He was cast into the depths of despair
There's no need to cover each point in depth[j4]a summary will do. [j33] In my next lecture I'll go into this topic in more depth
He started to explain the calculations, but soon got out of his depth. [j33] I was worried that if I accepted the supervisor's job, I'd be out of my depth
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See deep'.

definition: A deputation is a small group of people chosen to speak on behalf of a larger group.
example: The workers sent a deputation to the management to complain about safety conditions in the factory

definition: A deputy is someone who assists a person who is in charge of something, and acts on their behalf when they are away.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb deputise (or deputize)' Ari will deputise for Tim.  Tim deputised Ari to act for him.
example: David is my deputy

definition: Someone who is deranged is mentally ill and acts in a confused or violent way.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun derangement'
example: She became so deranged she had to be put in a psychiatric hospital

senses.definition: ' A derelict is someone who is homeless and neglected.
example: The derelict houses were bulldozed and a new sports centre was built on the site
In the most sophisticated of cities, you can still find derelicts sleeping under bridges and in parks
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun dereliction' The factory was in a state of dereliction when we took it over.

definition: In rather formal language, if you say that someone derides someone or some~ thing, you mean that they criticise them by making fun of them.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun derision' His speech was received with howls of derision.[j35]'adjective derisive' Their derisive laughter echoed behind us.
example: The other students derided him for his unfashionable clothes. [j33] Her theory was derided at the time, but has since been proved true

senses.definition: ' A derivative is something developed or made from something else.
example: Heroin and codeine are both derivatives of the same drug
' If something is derivative, it is not original but has been copied or adapted from something else.  This adjective is generally used as a criticism of ideas or artistic works

senses.definition: ' If you derive an answer or solution, you get it by working it out.
example: Jan derives great pleasure from collecting books. [j33] Fahim derives a good income from his restaurant. [j33] Many words in English are derived from Latin and Greek
From these figures we can derive the hourly speed. [j33] I derived from his letter that he'll be arriving next week. [j33] We pored over the map, trying to derive where we were
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See derivative'. [j35]'adjective See derivative'.

definition: Dermatitis is a medical condition in which the skin becomes inflamed, dry and itchy

example: The road descends sharply once it leaves the ridge. [j33] The lift descended to the ground floor
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is ascend.   2' descend on'  ' If someone or something descends on a place, they arrive suddenly and destructively. The rebels descended on the village and wiped it out.  The storm descended on the island with great force.  My mother descends on us once a year and criticises our housekeeping.   ... note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See descendant'.

example: The plane began its descent. [j33] Going up the hill was easy, but we found the descent was much harder
note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is ascent.   2' 'noun Your descent is your family origins. Michelle is of Chinese descent.

example: He described his trip to me in great detail. [j33] How would you describe the taste? [j33] I was able to describe my attacker to the police

senses.definition: ' If you are on a diet, you are careful about what and how much you eat, either because you want to lose weight or for medical reasons.
example: It's important to eat a healthy diet

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb diet' There's not much point in dieting without taking exercise as well.[j35]'adjective dietary' Adequate dietary fibre is essential for good health.

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See difference'. [j35]'adjective See different'.

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb See differ'.

senses.definition: ' If someone is difficult, they are awkward and hard to please.
example: Learning Chinese is very difficult for most English speakers. [j33] That book's too difficult for her[j4]she's only six. [j33] The firm faces difficult trading conditions. [j33] It was a difficult birth
Robert is an extremely difficult boss. [j33] Don't take any notice of Sandra[j4]she's in a difficult mood today. [j33] Some of the suppliers are being difficult about accepting our terms
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun difficulty (difficulties)' Have you had any difficulty settling in?   I opened the door with difficulty.

senses.definition: ' If someone's writing or speech is diffuse, it is not very clear, and its meaning is vague, perhaps because too many words are used.

senses.definition: 0' dig up'   (a) If you dig something up, you find or take it out of the ground after it's been buried or planted.
example: My mother just loves to dig in the garden. [j33] The dog was digging in the sand
We dug a deep pit at the bottom of the garden. [j33] They use heavy machinery to dig the foundations
They used to dig for gold in this area. [j33] The dog's in the backyard digging for his bone

Santa Claus dug into his bag and brought out a toy. [j33] I'll have to dig into my files for that information. 5 ' '[cf2]verb If you dig something into something, you push or poke it in.  [cf2]Julio dug the fork into his steak hungrily. [j33] The cat dug its claws into my leg. [j33] He dug his elbow into my side
Carl's always having a dig at me about my bad handwriting. [j33] That remark was a dig at Terry
' A dig is a place where archaeologists are digging up the ground to discover things which will tell us more about past times
We dug in and waited for the signal to start firing. '   (b) '[cf2] If you dig in, you firmly hold onto your position or opinion.  [cf2]I tried to reason ~with her, but she dug in

The emergency services are working to dig the survivors out of the building. [j33] Our car was bogged, and it took us three hours to dig it out of the mud. '   (b) '[cf2] If you dig something out, you find it after it's been stored or hidden for quite a long time.  [cf2]I'll dig out some old photos and show you what I looked like before I grew my beard

We'll have to dig up those plants and put them in a shady spot. [j33] The archaeologists dug up some pottery from the ruins. '   (b) '[cf2] If you dig up information, you discover it after a lot of careful searching.  [cf2]The reporter dug up some embarrassing information about the Prime Minister's past
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See digger'. [j35]'noun See diggings'.

senses.definition: ' dip out'   (a) If you dip out on an activity, you choose not to take part in it.
example: I dipped my toe into the water to see how cold it was. [j33] Dip the fish into the egg and milk mixture and then into the bread crumbs

'   (b) '[cf2] If you dip into a subject or a book, you study it for a short time or you read only parts of it.  [cf2]It's the sort of book you want to dip into rather than read right through. '   (c) '[cf2] If you dip into your savings, you use some of the money you've saved.  [cf2]Losing my job meant I had to dip into my savings, and I was getting worried

I'll have to dip out on the golf game next week[j4]it's my wife's birthday. '   (b) '[cf2] If you dip out on an exam, you fail it.  [cf2]James deserved to dip out[j4]he'd been loafing for the whole term

[j33] Please be direct with me. 4 ' '[cf2]adjective If someone is a direct descendant of someone in the past, they are descended in an unbroken line from parent to child rather than by a route involving brothers or sisters.  [cf2]He had no children and hence no direct descendants
He directed the gun at me. [j33] This question is directed at the treasurer. [j33] Not enough money is directed at education

senses.definition: b If you ~double something, or if it doubles, it's twice as big as it used to be.
example: We got double the amount of rain this year as last. [j33] This building is double the height of that one. [j33] You need to make it double that length. [j33] I got double as much as Sue
I ordered a double vodka. [j33] He bribed her with double pocket money. [j33] The recipe's for two, so for four use double quantities
Double doors lead onto the patio. [j33] I bought a double pack of light bulbs
I doubled the piece of paper and put it in my pocket

He's doubled his salary in the last three years. [j33] His salary has doubled. 6 '[cf2]verb If something doubles as something else, it can be used in two ways.  [cf2]The seats in my van unfold and double as a bed when we go camping. 7 '[cf2]verb If you double someone on your bike, you carry them on the back of it.  [cf2]His big brother doubled him to school every day. 8 '[cf2]noun Double is an amount that is twice as much as in other cases.  [cf2]I gave Lucy double, because she missed out last time. 9 '[cf2]noun A double is an actor who takes the place of another in a scene in a film.  Usually, the double and the actor look very alike.  [cf2]They used a double for the long process of setting up the shot. 10 '[cf2]noun A double is someone who looks very much like someone else.  [cf2]Laura is the double of her grandmother when she was her age. [j33] Are you sure you weren't there?  You must have a double! 11 'double back' '[cf2] If you double back, you go back the way you came.  [cf2]We got lost, so we doubled back to get our bearings again. 12 '[cf2] If you double up, you bend at the waist, either from pain or with laughter. [cf2]Jim doubled up in pain when she kicked him in the groin. [j33] If you tell them that, they'll double up laughing
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb doubly' It's doubly incon~ venient because my mother's visiting then.

definition: 1 When you drag something, you pull it along the ground, usually with a lot of effort.
rest: Why d@ y@u: ha:vE t@ dra:g tha:t u:p a:ga:i:n EvEry ti:mE wE ha:vE a: qu:a:rrEl?
example: His suitcase was so heavy he had to drag it up the stairs. [j33] The tractor dragged the stones into place. [j33] Don't drag your coat along the ground like that. 2 '[cf2]verb If someone drags you somewhere, they get you to go there even though you don't really want to.  [cf2]I had to drag Andrea to the party, but once she got there she really enjoyed it. [j33] As a child I was always being dragged round art exhibitions. 3 '[cf2]verb If you drag yourself somewhere, you force yourself to go there even though you're feeling tired or ill.  [cf2]Every morning I have to drag myself out of bed at 5 o'clock. [j33] You're not doing anyone any favours dragging yourself in and infecting us all. 4 '[cf2]verb If someone drags a river or lake, they pull up things from the bottom using nets and hooks.  [cf2]Police dragged the dam for the murder weapon. 5 '[cf2]verb If time or an event drags, it seems to pass very slowly because it's boring.  [cf2]The talk dragged on for two hours. [j33] Today's really dragged. 6 '[cf2]noun In informal language, if you say someone or something is a drag, you mean they're boring. [cf2]Mal's a drag[j4]all he can talk about is work, work, work! [j33] I find doing the washing up a real drag. [j33] It's a drag that we have to leave so early. 7 '[cf2]noun If you take a drag from a cigarette, cigar or pipe, you suck in air through it.  [cf2]He took a couple of drags from his pipe before replying. 8 '[cf2]noun When a man wears drag, he dresses up in women's clothing.  [cf2]It was a real challenge doing the whole part in drag. [j33] He went to the party in drag. 9 ~'[cf2]noun Drag is the force of air or water that acts against the forward motion of a car, plane or boat. [cf2]We polished the hull of our sailing boat to reduce drag. 10 'drag down' '[cf2] If someone or something drags you down, they make you feel depressed and pessimistic.  [cf2]Robin's really fed up[j4]his job seems to be dragging him down.  11 'drag into'  (a) '[cf2] If you are dragged into something, you become involved in it although you don't really want or need to be.  [cf2]I was dragged into their argument and forced to take sides.'  (b) '[cf2] If you drag a topic into a discussion or conversation,  you mention it although it's not really relevant.  [cf2]He always tries to drag his Asian trip into whatever we're talking about. 12' drag out'  (a) '[cf2] If you drag something out, you make it last much longer than is necessary. [cf2]She dragged the meeting out by getting everyone to give a report on their section.'  (b) '[cf2] If you drag information out of someone, you manage with great difficulty to get them to tell it to you. [cf2]Eventually we dragged out of him where he was really going. 13' drag up' '[cf2] If you drag something up, you mention something that happened in the past

senses.definition: ' down the drain' If something goes down the drain, it's wasted.
example: I drained the vegetables and served them up. [j33] The washing machine drains automatically at the end of the cycle
The water from the roof drains into these tanks
He was so thirsty he drained the glass of water in one go
The children certainly drain my patience. [j33] This heat really drains me
All my anger drained out of me when I saw how upset she ~was. [j33] I could feel my tension draining away as I lay in the warm bath
Having four kids is a big drain on their finances. [j33] The research division is a drain on our budget, but it's an essential investment for the future
There's a dreadful smell[j4] I think the drains must be blocked
All our hard work went down the drain when the proposal was rejected outright. [j33] Renting accommodation when you can afford to buy is just pouring money down the drain
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drainage' This is a fertile area with good drainage.[j35]'adjective drained' The experience left me emotionally drained.[j35]'adjective draining' It was a very draining experience.

example: I drained the vegetables and served them up. [j33] The washing machine drains automatically at the end of the cycle
The water from the roof drains into these tanks
He was so thirsty he drained the glass of water in one go
The children certainly drain my patience. [j33] This heat really drains me
All my anger drained out of me when I saw how upset she ~was. [j33] I could feel my tension draining away as I lay in the warm bath
Having four kids is a big drain on their finances. [j33] The research division is a drain on our budget, but it's an essential investment for the future
There's a dreadful smell[j4] I think the drains must be blocked
All our hard work went down the drain when the proposal was rejected outright. [j33] Renting accommodation when you can afford to buy is just pouring money down the drain
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drainage' This is a fertile area with good drainage.[j35]'adjective drained' The experience left me emotionally drained.[j35]'adjective draining' It was a very draining experience.

definition: A drake is a male duck

Drama is a compulsory part of the literature course. [j33] She studied drama at university

senses.definition: Dramatic means relating to plays, the theatre and acting.
example: He told me about his dramatic escape from his country. [j33] There have been further dramatic developments in the case
There's been a dramatic change in her attitude lately. [j33] I decided to do something really dramatic and had my hair cut short and dyed blond
Her mother was a large, dramatic woman
The amateur actors put on several dramatic pro~ ductions a year. [j33] She trained at the National Institute for Dramatic Art in Sydney
note: [j34] ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb dramatically' He paused dramatically before speaking.   She had changed dramatically.

senses.definition: If you dramatise something, you make it seem much more exciting or serious than it really is.
example: Quite a few Australian novels have been dramatised in recent years[j4]I saw one on TV just the other night

note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is dramatize.  [j32] ... WORD FAMILY 'noun dramatisation' The series is a dramatisation of Ned Kelly's life.

definition: A drawback is a disadvantage.  It is a bad aspect of a situation which in other ways is quite agreeable to you.
rest: [cb8][mgdi:ct_dra:wEr,-4][mgdi:ct_dra:wEr,-1][@l0][cb0][qr
example: One drawback with working in town is that the traffic in peak hour makes travelling very slow.  ~--drawcard 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]dr[j20]kad' '[cf2]noun If you call an entertainer or some special event a drawcard, you mean that they are likely to attract a large audience

senses.definition: The drawer of a cheque is the person who writes it.  By writing the cheque they are instructing their bank to draw money from their account to pay someone else.

definition: If someone drawls, they speak slowly with long vowels in their words.

senses.definition: If someone is drawn, they look tired and anxious.
example: Her face was drawn from the ordeal she'd been through

definition: If you dread something, you are very afraid of it or worried about it.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun dread' There's an atmosphere of dread about the place.  The boys are in dread of him.
example: I used to dread coming home to a dark, empty house. [j33] I'm really dreading the exams. [j33] I dread to think what'll happen when she finds out

senses.definition: If something is dreadful, it is of very poor quality.
example: Apparently Felix had a dreadful time on his trip. [j33] I got in a dreadful mess with the recipe. [j33] He's a dreadful bore. [j33] It's a dreadful nuisance
He showed ~us some really dreadful watercolours he'd done
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb dreadfully' I'm dreadfully sorry.  It's dreadfully inconvenient.

comment: verb forms dreams, dreamed or dreamt, dreaming
definition: 1 A dream is all the thoughts and pictures that pass through your mind when you are asleep.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See Dreaming'. [j35]'dream verb' I was dreaming about a tropical island.  She would dream of a better future.[j35]'noun dreamer' Charlotte's a dreamer[j4]we need someone with a practical outlook.
example: I had a dream about my grandmother last night. [j33] The answer came to me in a dream. 2 '[cf2]noun A dream is a hope that you have for the future.  [cf2]Her head was filled with dreams of fame and fortune. [j33] It was my father's dream to live in Australia. 3 '[cf2]noun In informal language, if you say something is a dream, you mean that you think it's very attractive or desirable.  [cf2]Peter's new house is a dream[j4]plenty of room for guests and it has ocean views

definition: According to Abori[chginal beliefs, the Dreaming is the time when the Earth was given its present form and the patterns and cycles of nature began

definition: 1 If something is dreary, it makes you feel sad and gloomy.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb drearily' [j35]'noun dreariness'
example: It rained all week and we spent a dreary time at the seaside. 2 '[cf2]adjective If something is dreary, it is dull and uninteresting. [cf2]His lectures are always very dreary

definition: If you drench something, you make it thoroughly wet.
example: We got drenched in the sudden shower

I like wearing brightly coloured dresses in winter

senses.definition: 'get someone's drift In informal language, if you tell someone you get their drift, you mean you understand what they're saying.
example: The boat drifted down the river. [j33] A lot of empty cans were drifting towards the bank. [j33] Clouds drifted across the sky
So many young people seem to be content just to drift. [j33] Last year I was just drifting[j4]now I really want to take some courses and get a better job
I get your drift[j4] you want me to come and support you? [j33] She explained it once more and I began to get the drift. [j33] I don't know Chinese well, but I got the drift of the conversation
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drifter' Anton's a drifter[j4] he never sticks at any job for long.

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See drunk'.[j35]'noun drinker' Henry's a heavy drinker.
example: I ~was so thirsty I drank three glasses of water straight off. [j33] Can I get you something to drink? 2 '[cf2]verb If someone drinks, they drink alcohol.  [cf2]Don't drink and drive. [j33] His career went downhill and he began to drink heavily. [j33] I don't drink, thank you. 3 '[cf2]noun A drink is a liquid refreshment such as a cup of tea or coffee or a glass of beer or wine.  [cf2]Would you like a drink? [j33] I was desperate for a drink

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5]dr[j11][j18]k-[j24]dra[j11]v[j11][j18]' Drink- driving is the driving of a car, motorbike or other vehicle when you have more alcohol in your blood than the law says you should.
example: He has to go to court tomorrow because of drink-driving[j4]he was over the legal limit

definition: 1a If a liquid drips, it falls in small drops.
example: Water was dripping from the tap. [j33] The coffee machine's leaking[j4]there's coffee dripping on the new carpet. b '[cf2]verb If something drips, it lets a liquid fall in small drops.  [cf2]The tap in the bathroom is dripping. [j33] Your wet clothes are dripping onto the floor[j4]you'd better put them outside. 2 '[cf2]noun A drip is an intravenous injection.  You have drugs or nutrition slowly injected into a vein in your arm from a container on a stand beside you.  [cf2]After the operation, Aldo was put on a drip because he couldn't eat. 3 '[cf2]noun In informal language, if you call someone a drip, you mean that they are silly or feeble.  [cf2]Don't be a drip, of course they won't mind

example: 5][j24]dr[j11]p-dra[j11]' When drip-dry garments are washed, they can be hung on the line to dry and they won't need ironing

definition: Dripping is animal fat which has melted out of meat being cooked and has then dried into a solid state
example: It can be used as a fat for cooking

comment: verb forms drives, drove, driven, driving
definition: 1a If you drive a vehicle, you control it so that the engine makes it go where you want.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun driver' The truck driver lost control of his vehicle.
example: Suree drove the car up the hill. [j33] What sort of car do you drive? [j33] Can you drive a tractor? [j33] Applicants must be able to drive a forklift truck. b '[cf2]verb If you drive, you travel in a vehicle.  [cf2]We ~drove to Darwin last year. [j33] 'How do you get to work?' 'I usually drive or get a lift from a neighbour.' c '[cf2]noun A drive is a trip in a vehicle. [cf2]We went for a drive in the Blue Mountains. [j33] It's a long drive from Brisbane to Melbourne. 2 '[cf2]verb If something drives something, it moves it using some type of energy.  [cf2]The steam drives the motors to produce electricity. [j33] The ship was driven by two engines. 3 '[cf2]verb If something drives something somewhere, it makes it go there.  [cf2]The cat drove all the birds away. [j33] The rain has driven the holiday- makers inside. 4 '[cf2] In informal language, if you say that something drives you mad, you mean that it makes you so irritated that you find it difficult to cope.  [cf2]Sydney traffic drives Krista mad, so she's moving to the country. [j33] That noise is driving me mad. [j33] The kids are enough to drive anyone mad. 5 '[cf2]noun A drive is a path leading to a private house.  [cf2]There were five cars parked in the drive. [j33] I heard her car in the drive. 6 '[cf2]noun If you have drive, you have a lot of energy and are very eager to achieve what you want.  [cf2]We must employ someone with a lot of drive to get this job done

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]dra[j11]v-[j11]n'  1 A drive-in is an open- air cinema where you watch the movies sitting in your car.
example: What's on at the drive-in tonight? 2 '[cf2]adjective At a drive-in business, customers are served in their cars.  [cf2]The new fast-food place up the road has a drive-in counter. [j33] There's a drive-in bottle shop near the station

definition: A [chdriver's licence is an official document that allows you to drive a vehicle on public roads.  There are different types of licences for different vehicles. You have to pass a knowledge test and a driving test to get a driver's licence.
example: I'd better go and renew my driver's licence today

definition: A driveway is a path for cars, especially one that leads from the road to your front door or your garage
A driving test is a practical examination in which you have to show that you can drive a car safely and know the traffic rules before you get a driver's licence.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drizzle' It's not raining hard[j4]just a drizzle.
example: Raymond's failed his driving test for the third time.  ~--drizzle 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]dr[j11]z[j17]l' '[cf2]verb If it drizzles, it rains lightly. [cf2]It's drizzling outside[j4]you'd better put a raincoat on

definition: If something drones, it makes a low-pitched, dull monotonous sound.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drone' From our window we can hear the drone of traffic on the highway.
example: It's hard to concentrate with the planes droning overhead every few minutes. [j33] The speaker's voice droned on in the background

definition: In informal language, a drongo 'is someone who is not intelligent

senses.definition: If something droops, it becomes limp or bends, so that it's hanging down.
example: The flowers in the vase had drooped because of lack of water. [j33] Her head was drooping with tiredness. 2 '[cf2]verb If your spirits droop, you become discou~ [chraged.  You start to lose your determination to keep going.  [cf2]Their spirits drooped when they realised the hut was still four hours' walk away

definition: 1a A drop is a small amount of liquid that falls somewhere.
rest: [ct
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See droplet'. [j35]'noun See drop-out'. [j35]'noun See dropper'. [j35]'noun See droppings'. [xc--droplet 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]dr[j16]pl[j17]t' 'noun A droplet is a small drop of liquid.
example: I'm sure I felt a drop of rain. [j33] TAKE TEN DROPS OF THIS MEDICINE THREE TIMES A DAY. b '[cf2]noun A drop is a small amount of liquid.  [cf2]Could I have a drop of milk, please? [j33] 'Would you like a whisky?'  'Just a drop, please.' 2a '[cf2]verb If you drop something, you let go of it so that it falls to the ground.  [cf2]I dropped the parcel on the table. [j33] The helicopter dropped food to people isolated by the floods. [j33] Be careful not to drop it[j4]it's fragile. b '[cf2]verb If something drops, it falls towards the ground.  [cf2]The plane dropped like a stone when the engine cut out. c '[cf2]noun A drop is the distance from the top to the bottom of something.  [cf2]These curtains have a drop of two metres. [j33] There's a sheer drop of 100 metres from the cliff down to the beach. 3a '[cf2]verb When you drop something, you make it lower.  [cf2]Ermano dropped his voice. [j33] That dress is too short for me[j4]I'll have to drop the hem a bit. [j33] The supermarket down the road has dropped meat prices for a week. b '[cf2]verb If something drops, it becomes less or goes down in value.  [cf2]Petrol prices dropped by four cents per litre yesterday. [j33] The dollar has dropped against the ~yen. c '[cf2]noun A drop is a lessening in amount or value.  [cf2]There was a ten per cent drop in the value of the dollar overnight. [j33] If workers are not given a pay increase, their wages will have taken a consid~ erable drop in real terms. 4 '[cf2]verb If you drop something such as a school subject or a course, you stop studying or attending it.  [cf2]Renee dropped the textiles course and took up catering instead. 5a '[cf2]verb If you drop someone, you set them down from a car or bus.  [cf2]My husband dropped me at the railway station. [j33] Bus number 431 will drop you right outside our door. b '[cf2]verb If you drop someone, you stop being friends with them.  [cf2]Cynthia's a bit of a bore[j4]I've been trying to drop her for months. 6a '[cf2]verb If you drop someone a note or a line, you write to them in a fairly informal way. [cf2]Drop us a line when you get to Rome. [j33] Juan dropped his mother a note from Uluru. b '[cf2]verb If you drop a hint, you hope that someone will guess something from what you say, without you telling them directly.  [cf2]My boss dropped a hint about my pay today[j4]I think I'm in for a raise. 7 'drop in or by '[cf2] If you drop in or by, you go to a person's home for a short, informal visit.  [cf2]I dropped in to Barbara's place for a cup of coffee. [j33] I just dropped by to get that recipe. 8 'drop off '[cf2] If you drop someone off, you set them down from your car after giving them a lift.  [cf2]Drop me off at the next corner[j4]I can easily walk to the station from there. 9 '[cf2] If you drop out of a course of study, you abandon it without finishing it.  [cf2]Paul dropped out of the course after only two weeks

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5][j24]dr[j16]p-a[j23]t' A drop-out is someone who abandons a course of study without finishing it or who chooses to live a life that's different from the rest of society.
example: A high school drop-out, he was a millionaire by the age of thirty. [j33] Many of these plots of land are bought by drop-outs seeking an alternative way of life

Droppings are bits of animal dung.
example: You can hardly walk along the footpaths ~around here because of all the dog droppings

senses.definition: If one sound drowns another, the first one is so loud that you can't hear the second one.

The marketing department is drowning in returned questionnaires. [j33] For the first three weeks I was drowning in work. 3 '[cf2]verb If someone drowns a person or animal, they kill them by holding their head under water so that they can't breathe
The noise of the traffic drowned their voices

definition: 1 A drug is a chemical substance which produces changes in the body or the mind. Some drugs are used as medicines to cure sickness but others are illegal because people take them for pleasure and then become addicted.
example: Nicotine and caffeine are habit-forming drugs. [j33] The police broke into the flat looking for illegal drugs. 2 '[cf2]verb If someone drugs someone, they give them a chemical substance to make them partly or fully unconscious. [cf2]The woman was drugged and her money stolen

definition: 1 A drum is a musical instru~ ~ment with a round, hollow body and skin stretched tightly over one of the ends.  You beat the skin with a stick or your hands to make a sound. 2 '
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drummer' They're looking for a new drummer for the band.
example: verb If you drum, you play the drum or make a rhythmic sound like the beat of a drum, for example with your fingers on a table.  [cf2]He drummed his fingers with impatience. 3 '[cf2]noun A drum is a tall cylindrical container used to store liquids. [cf2]When we went out bush, we took two petrol drums on the back of our truck. 4 'drum into '[cf2] If you drum something into someone, you make them remem~ ber it by saying it forcefully several times.  [cf2]Our teacher drummed the maths tables into our heads. [j33] My mother drummed it into me never to go in the yard with bare feet. 5 'drum up '[cf2] If you drum up business or support, you get people to buy things from you or support your ideas.  [cf2]We held a sale to drum up trade. [j33] She's very good at drumming up enthusiasm in her team

definition: 1 A drumstick is a long, thin piece of wood that you use to play a drum. 2 '
example: noun A drumstick is the lower part of a chicken's leg.  [cf2]My brother always chooses a drumstick to eat when we have chicken for dinner

senses.definition: A drunk is someone who has consumed too much alcohol, or who does so regularly.
example: After ten cans of beer, he was completely drunk
The police arrested two drunks outside the pub
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun drunkard' As his career declined he became a drunkard.[j35]'adjective drunken' He gave a drunken leer.  Three drunken louts drove by.

definition: 1a If something is dry, it is not wet or damp.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun See drier'.
example: I want a dry shirt[j4] this one's still damp. [j33] We need dry wood, otherwise the fire won't burn. b '[cf2]adjective If the weather is dry, there is no rain.  [cf2]This has been a very dry winter. [j33] The tropical north of Australia has a wet season and a dry season. 2a '[cf2]verb If you dry something, you make it dry.  [cf2]Kira dried her hair in front of the mirror. [j33] I need a clean towel to dry ~myself. b '[cf2]verb If something dries, it becomes dry. [cf2]Clothes dry quickly in the sun. [j33] Don't touch the wall[j4]the paint takes hours to dry. 3 '[cf2]adjective If wine, sherry or cider is dry, it is not sweet. 4 '[cf2]adjective If no alcohol is allowed in a particular place by law, we say the area is dry.  [cf2] 5 '[cf2]adjective If something is dry, it is dull and uninteresting. [cf2]Law can be a very dry subject. [j33] I tried to make my lectures a little less dry. 6 '[cf2]adjective A dry remark is something humorous that is said in a flat, unemotional way.  The person talking does not look as though they are saying something funny. [cf2]My father has a wonderful dry sense of humour. 7 'the dry '[cf2] The dry is the dry season in the tropical north of Australia.  [cf2]The best time to travel to the Top End is in the dry

example: This blouse has to be dry-cleaned

definition: Dual is used to describe something that has two parts.

example: The driving school uses cars with dual controls. [j33] This plan had a dual purpose

definition: If a movie is dubbed, it is given a soundtrack in a different language so that audiences overseas can understand it
1 If you are dubious about something, you're uncertain or anxious about it.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb dubiously' She prodded it dubiously.
example: I was dubious about approaching her. [j33] I'm highly dubious that it'll work. 2 '[cf2]adjective  If something is dubious, you aren't sure whether it can be trusted or relied on.  [cf2]This new building project looks rather dubious to me[j4]we need to check whether it satisfies safety regulations

senses.definition: In cricket, you score a duck when you are batting if you get out before you score any runs.
example: There were three ducks waddling along the river bank
Willie ducked his little brother in the swimming pool
Steve was out for a duck
note: ... NOTE that a male duck is called a drake.   2 'verb If you duck, you crouch down quickly to avoid being seen or being hit by something.  Joe ducked behind the fence when he saw his mother approaching.  The soldiers ducked back into their trenches as the bombardment began.

senses.definition: 'dues Dues are membership fees that you pay to a club or an association.
example: Club membership fees are due in August. [j33] The due date shown on this account is next Friday
The bus is due at 7 o'clock. [j33] My husband's due back from Bangkok on Friday. [j33] The annual meeting's due sometime around June
His poor examination results are partly due to family problems. [j33] Due to staff shortages, we won't be able to deliver the computer today
After due consideration the appeal was rejected. [j33] In due time you'll forget all about your present troubles

They drove due west through the bush to find their way back to camp. 6 '[cf2]noun If you give someone their due, you give them praise or credit for something they've done. [cf2]Let's give him his due for a job well done. [j33] To give him his due, he did apologise when he realised his mistake
Only twenty members have paid their dues so far this year
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adverb See duly'.

note: ... WORD FAMILY 'verb dull' This injection should dull the pain.[j35]'adverb dully' My leg throbbed dully.[j35] 'noun dullness'
example: Life in the country can be pretty dull. [j33] We spent a dull day in the park. [j33] Dr Matthews' lectures are always terribly dull. example: The young actor was duly awarded the prize for her outstanding performance. [j33] I hope that you're duly grateful. [j33] She asked us to come back at three and we duly returned on time

example: Ever since the accident she has been dumb. [j33] The old man preferred the company of dumb animals to humans. 2 '[cf2]adjective If you are dumb, you can't speak because you are surprised or amazed. When I saw Hilda she was down in the dumps[j4]let's go and try to cheer her up

example: I had beef stew with herb dumplings

definition: If someone is dumpy, they are short and plump

note: ... A SIMILAR WORD for this is manure.
example: The children had great fun tumbling from the top of the dune down to the water's edge.  ~--dung 'times,0'[cp8.5]d... [j18]' '[cf2]noun Dung is the faeces from animals. [cf2]Cow dung is an excellent natural food for the garden

definition: If you dunk something, you dip it in water or some other liquid.

example: They performed as a violin and piano duo

example: I prefer a small garden so I'll buy a duplex instead of a house

senses.definition: A duplicate is something which is exactly the same as something else.
example: Please duplicate these letters for me. 2 '[cf2]verb If you duplicate something, you create something else which is exactly the same as it.  [cf2]We must ensure that we do not duplicate the services already provided by other organisations
I went through my stamp collection to weed out the duplicates
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective duplicate' Some depart~ ments provide duplicate services[j4]it's very inefficient.[j35] 'noun duplication' We have to avoid duplication of government services.

example: It's better to buy good quality shoes as they are much more durable ~than cheaper ones. [j33] This film has proved to be a durable classic

example: The maximum duration of a travel pass is one year. [j33] Many hotels are offering reduced rates for the duration of the industrial dispute

definition: If something happens during a particular period of time, it happens at some point in that period or throughout the whole of it.

example: Enrico made a lot of friends during his holidays. [j33] Violence broke out among spectators during the soccer match. [j33] The Prime Minister was interrupted five times during his speech

definition: 1 A duty is something which you are morally or legally obliged to do.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective See duty-free'.[j35]'adjective dutiable' All imports in excess of the duty-free allowance are dutiable.[j35]'adjective dutiful' I'm sick of being a dutiful daughter.[j35]'adverb dutifully' I dutifully wrote to thank them for the present.
example: I felt it my duty to help her. [j33] It is your duty to provide full and accurate information about every accident. [j33] The council has clearly failed in its duty of care. 2 '[cf2]noun A duty is something that you have to do as an essential part of your job.  [cf2]My duties include record keeping and filing. [j33] A statement of the duties of this position may be obtained from the personnel department. [j33] ...night duty.  3 '[cf2]noun A duty is a payment or tax that has to be paid to the government when goods are imported or exported or certain documents are signed.  [cf2]We had to pay import duty on the jewellery we bought abroad. [j33] You must pay stamp duty when you buy a house. 4 'off duty '[cf2] If you are off duty, you are not working.  You are having time off from work.  [cf2]What time do you come off duty tonight? [j33] How do you spend your time off duty? 5 'on duty '[cf2] If you are on duty, you are working.  [cf2]What time do you go on duty tonight? [j33] How many days a month are you on duty? [j33] Drinking on duty is strictly forbidden

definition: 'times,0'[cp8.5]djuti-[j24]fri' If something is duty- free, no import duty or sales tax needs to be paid on it.
example: Every overseas traveller can buy duty-free goods up to a certain limit

definition: Duvet is another word for doona'
1 In fairytales, a dwarf is a small human- like being who has magic powers.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'adjective dwarf' I planted dwarf sweet peas in my garden.
example: My daughter loves the story of Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs. 2 '[cf2]noun A dwarf is someone who is much smaller than the usual size because of a genetic condition.  It is considered insulting to refer to these people as 'dwarves'; they prefer to be called 'small people' or 'little people'. 3 '[cf2]verb If something ~dwarfs something else, it is very much larger than it.  [cf2]Tim already dwarfs his mother and he's only twelve years old. [j33] The new hotel dwarfed the lovely old colonial church next to it

comment: verb forms dwells, dwelt or dwelled, dwelling
definition: 1 In formal language, if you say that someone dwells somewhere or in a certain condition, you mean that that's where or how they live.
note: ... WORD FAMILY 'noun dwelling' They live in a temporary dwelling constructed from scraps of wood.
example: They dwelt in peace and harmony. [j33] Hansel and Gretel dwelt in a small house on the edge of the forest. 2 'dwell on '[cf2] If you dwell on something, you spend a good deal of time speaking, writing or thinking about it.  Possibly you spend more time than is necessary or sensible.  [cf2]The speaker dwelt on the political situation in Indonesia. [j33] I'd like to dwell on this point a bit longer. [j33] There's no point in dwelling on the past

definition: If something dwindles, it becomes less or smaller.
example: My savings dwindled rapidly when I was out of work. [j33] I could sense their enthusiasm for the task dwindling as the hours went by

senses.definition: If you say that something is dynamite, you mean that it is very exciting and impressive or it has a devastating effect.
example: The dynamite blasted a huge hole in the mountain
The young actor is dynamite in her second film role. [j33] These documents will be political dynamite if they're published

definition: Dysentery is a serious infectious disease in which the bowel is inflamed, causing diarrhoea containing blood and mucus.
example: Vishal fell ill with dysentery while working out in the bush. [j33] Lack of clean water and proper hygiene causes dysentery
